SENT.plain: OBJECTIVE: The purpose of this study was to determine the extent to which patients omit doses of medications prescribed for diabetes

RESEARCH DESIGN AND METHODS: A literature search (1966-2003) was performed to identify reports with quantitative data on adherence with oral hypoglycemic agents (OHAs) and insulin and correlations between adherence rates and glycemic control
Adequate documentation of adherence was found in 15 retrospective studies of OHA prescription refill rates, 5 prospective electronic monitoring OHA studies, and 3 retrospective insulin studies
RESULTS: Retrospective analyses showed that adherence to OHA therapy ranged from 36 to 93% in patients remaining on treatment for 6-24 months
Prospective electronic monitoring studies documented that patients took 67-85% of OHA doses as prescribed
Electronic monitoring identified poor compliers for interventions that improved adherence (61-79%; P < 0.05)
Young patients filled prescriptions for one-third of prescribed insulin doses
Insulin adherence among patients with type 2 diabetes was 62-64%
CONCLUSIONS: This review confirms that many patients for whom diabetes medication was prescribed were poor compliers with treatment, including both OHAs and insulin
However, electronic monitoring systems were useful in improving adherence for individual patients
Similar electronic monitoring systems for insulin administration could help healthcare providers determine patients needing additional support
